description: Late 16th c., from French capuchin, from earlier capucin, from Italian cappuccino, ultimately from Late Latin cappa (“cape, hood”).

entries.meaning: A monk in the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin; (generally) a Franciscan.
examples: “That is something,” said the capuchin, “but not the most essential. Are you certain that he is a Christian?”

entries.meaning: A garment consisting of a cloak and hood, made in imitation of the dress of Capuchin monks.
examples: Of Ermine is his doublet — / His Capuchin gay —
